original_data.question: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a cough that her parents are worried about. She has had a runny nose and a low-grade fever for the past 2 days, with some hoarseness and a rough-sounding cough that started this afternoon. This evening she began making some high-pitched sounds when taking breaths, and she seemed to be having some trouble breathing. She is alert and does not appear to be in acute distress. She has a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4 °F), with a respiratory rate of 50/min and O2 saturation of 97%. There is audible inspiratory stridor that worsens when she starts to cry during the examination. She has an occasional barking cough. Her pharynx is mildly erythematous with normal tonsils and no exudate. A frontal X-ray of the upper chest airways is obtained (shown in the image). Which of the following is the best step in management?

options.A: Anterior-posterior and lateral radiographs of the neck
options.B: Racemic epinephrine and intramuscular corticosteroid therapy
options.D: Trial of bronchodilator therapy and oral steroids

model_response:
The radiograph shows a normal-sized epiglottis and aryepiglottic folds, but the arytenoids and subglottic area are abnormal. The cricoid area is normal. The best step in management is to give racemic epinephrine and intramuscular corticosteroid therapy (option B). This patient has croup, which is a viral infection of the upper airway. The X-ray shows the characteristic subglottic narrowing or steeple sign. Racemic epinephrine can be given to help relieve the upper airway obstruction. Intramuscular dexamethasone is also given to help relieve the inflammation. Antibiotics are not indicated because this is a viral infection. A trial of bronchodilator therapy and oral steroids (option D) would be indicated if the patient had wheezing and signs of lower airway obstruction. The patient should be admitted to the hospital because she may need additional doses of epinephrine and steroids, and close observation for possible airway obstruction.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.

A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. It is a protective response that serves to clear the trachea, bronchi, and/or lungs of irritants and secretions, or to prevent aspiration of foreign materials into the lungs.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
A discharge of fluid from the nose.

A precancerous neoplastic process that affects the cervical squamous epithelium without evidence of invasion. It is usually associated with human papillomavirus infection. It is characterized by the presence of mild atypia in the superficial epithelial layer that may be associated with koilocytosis. Maturation is present in the upper two thirds of the epithelium. Mitotic figures are not numerous and are present in the basal third of the epithelium.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
An unnaturally deep or rough quality of voice.
The time period between noon and sunset.
The time period between late afternoon and bedtime.
An abnormal increase in the pitch (frequency) of the voice. [HPO:probinson]

A type of non-ionizing radiation in which energy is transmitted through solid, liquid, or gas as compression waves. Sound (acoustic or sonic) radiation with frequencies above the audible range is classified as ultrasonic. Sound radiation below the audible range is classified as infrasonic.
The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.
Taking ambient air into the lungs; breathing in.
A state of physiological or psychological stress that cannot be compensated for by normal adaptive measures.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.

The determination of oxygen-hemoglobin saturation of blood either by withdrawing a sample and passing it through a classical photoelectric oximeter or by electrodes attached to some translucent part of the body like finger, earlobe, or skin fold. It includes non-invasive oxygen monitoring by pulse oximetry.
Taking ambient air into the lungs; breathing in.
A symptom resulting from laryngeal obstruction. It is characterized by a high pitched breathing sound.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Not occurring regularly or at short intervals.
A cough with a characteristic sound that has been compared to a seal's bark. [PMID:16936230, PMID:28613724]

A funnel-shaped fibromuscular tube that conducts food to the ESOPHAGUS, and air to the LARYNX and LUNGS. It is located posterior to the NASAL CAVITY; ORAL CAVITY; and LARYNX, and extends from the SKULL BASE to the inferior border of the CRICOID CARTILAGE anteriorly and to the inferior border of the C6 vertebra posteriorly. It is divided into the NASOPHARYNX; OROPHARYNX; and HYPOPHARYNX (laryngopharynx).

A round-to-oval mass of lymphoid tissue embedded in the lateral wall of the PHARYNX. There is one on each side of the oropharynx in the fauces between the anterior and posterior pillars of the SOFT PALATE.

Material, such as purulent and nonpurulent fluid, cells, or cellular debris, which has escaped from blood vessels and has been deposited in tissues or on tissue surfaces, usually as a result of inflammation. An exudate, in contrast to a transudate, is characterized by a relatively high protein content.
Of, or related to, or in the direction of the front of the body.
The sinuses and those parts of the respiratory system above the trachea. It includes the nares, nasopharynx, oropharynx, larynx, vocal cords, glottis and upper trachea.

Description:A characteristic representing a single file reference that contains two or more views of the same dosage form of the product; in most cases this should represent front and back views of the dosage form, but occasionally additional views might be needed in order to capture all of the important physical characteristics of the dosage form. Any imprint and/or symbol should be clearly identifiable, and the viewer should not normally need to rotate the image in order to read it. Images that are submitted with SPL should be included in the same directory as the SPL file.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
